content: I felt like it'd be appropriate to put this in a separate thread to the #combinatorial-games > Nimbers thread. An acquaintance (Rachel L. A. Hunter) recently communicated a proof that every nimber of the form φ(1@ω, x@0) is transcendental (where the notation is Veblen's multivariate function). In particular, the next transcendental is at most the Small Veblen Ordinal, giving a partial answer to a conjecture by Lenstra. I've gone over the proof and though I can't say I completely grasp it, it does seem correct.
Here's the document, shared with permission: nimtrans.pdf

For reference, here's a Lean definition of the multivariate Veblen function. The description on Wikipedia is kind of confusing, though admittedly so is this. 

import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Max
import Mathlib.Data.Finsupp.Single
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Veblen

namespace Ordinal

noncomputable def veblen₀ (f : Ordinal →₀ Ordinal) : Ordinal :=
  let g := f.erase 0
  if hg : g = 0 then ω ^ f 0 else
    let e := g.support.min' (Finsupp.support_nonempty_iff.2 hg)
    derivFamily
      (fun (x : Set.Iio (f e) × Set.Iio e) o ↦ veblen₀ ((g.update e x.1).update x.2 o)) (f 0)
termination_by f -- with colex order
decreasing_by sorry

end Ordinal

The notation (a₁@b₁, ..., aₙ@bₙ) is simply the finitely supported function with f(aᵢ) = bᵢ and f(x) = 0 otherwise.

The secret sauce here is the definition C(α,p)C(\alpha, p)C(α,p). For ppp a nimber polynomial whose coefficients are less than α\alphaα, this is the smallest nimber F≥αF\ge\alphaF≥α such that every non-constant polynomial q:F[X]q : F[X]q:F[X] with q<pq < pq<p contains a root/splits in FFF.

She proves by induction on ppp that if p0=0p_0=0p0​=0, then α<φ(pn,…,p1,β)\alpha < \varphi(p_n,\ldots,p_1,\beta)α<φ(pn​,…,p1​,β) implies C(α,p)≤φ(pn,…,p1,β)C(\alpha,p)\le \varphi(p_n,\ldots,p_1,\beta)C(α,p)≤φ(pn​,…,p1​,β). Which then straightforwardly implies the claimed result.

If I'm not mistaken, her proof in fact proves the stronger statement that α<φ(pn,…,p1,β)\alpha<\varphi(p_n,\ldots,p_1,\beta)α<φ(pn​,…,p1​,β) implies C(α,p)≤φ(pn,…,p1,β+p0)C(\alpha,p)\le\varphi(p_n,\ldots,p_1,\beta+p_0)C(α,p)≤φ(pn​,…,p1​,β+p0​), where of course p0p_0p0​ can now be anything else.
I guess I can try porting it to Lean
Well, I would like to be methodic about this.
what does that mean
I would like to first distill the argument into its bare components

I think there's a lemma about C(α,p)C(\alpha,p)C(α,p) which goes implicit in the document but which we probably want to show explicitly. Again, assume that I'm not mistaken.

Let ppp be a nimber polynomial and let α\alphaα be larger than all its coefficients. Let ddd be the "co-degree" of ppp, i.e. the index of the least non-zero coefficient. Define α0=α\alpha_0=\alphaα0​=α and αn+1=⨆qC(αn,q)\alpha_{n+1}=\bigsqcup_q C(\alpha_n,q)αn+1​=⨆q​C(αn​,q) where q:αn[X]q:\alpha_n[X]q:αn​[X] goes over all polynomials with q<pq<pq<p and where pk=qkp_k=q_kpk​=qk​ for every k>dk>dk>d. Define αω\alpha_\omegaαω​ as the supremum of αn\alpha_nαn​ for n:Nn : \mathbb Nn:N. Then C(α,p)≤αωC(\alpha,p)\le \alpha_\omegaC(α,p)≤αω​.
I think that this lemma allows us to unify the m=0m=0m=0 and m>0m>0m>0 successor cases in the document.
Oh and of course. Before we do any of this we'd have to formalize Veblen's multivariate function itself. I think I can take care of that.

Violeta Hernández said:

For reference, here's a Lean definition of the multivariate Veblen function. The description on Wikipedia is kind of confusing, though admittedly so is this.

this is the first definition I've seen that I can remember and not have to go back and look it up
Veblen's multivariate function is just inherently confusing I think
φ(1, 0, 0) is a fixed point of φ(-, 0) though not necessarily of φ(x, -)
unfortunately it doesn't seem to define the correct function
my definition or Wikipedia's?
your definition
No maybe I just misread it
no this is probably fine
no yeah this is fine
it's so confusing
I'm confirming everything up to Γ0\Gamma_0Γ0​ and then I will assume it's correct
wouldn't Γ0\Gamma_0Γ0​ be the case where ppp is a linear polynomial which is trivial anyways?
confirming the output of your definition of Veblen
ah
It seems to be doing fine
I'm guess the first thing to do is to prove the Veblen function terminates then?
Well
What we really need to do is define the order instance for docs#Colex of a docs#Finsupp
the API should be pretty much copy and paste from the docs#Lex API
I think it's not particularly controversial to say the multivariate Veblen function belongs in our repo rather than Mathlib
I'm currently working on PR-ing the Preorder (Colex (α →₀ β)) instance to Mathlib
Once we have that it shouldn't be very difficult to prove termination

This might take a while
image.png
Turns out there's way more dependent PRs for this colex stuff than I was anticipating. What do you think about just putting it in our repo for the time being?
